author: Anonymous Gear
title: atomic non-distinct vs distinct for boolean and false
question: Hi, I am a little confused why false is an atomic distinct value because I thought it was a Boolean which is an atomic non-distinct value? Or to phrase it differently, what is the difference between the false in the atomic distinct and Boolean in the atomic non-distinct?
student_answer:
If I understand it correctly, atomic distinct means there's "a single specific value" like false.
On the other hand, atomic non-distinct types of data like a Boolean do not fit that definition, because they can be true or false.

To use the other example shown in that table, "red" is a single specific value and is atomic distinct but Strings in general could be any String ("green" "apple" "" etc.)

One of the following videos about the New Year's countdown is helpful I think for clarifying this distinction
